projectDesc.p: "Sermon on St. Nobody" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Vir erat in oriente, Nemo nomine, et erat uir ille ut allter Iob inter omnes orientales.
app.rdg: There was a man in the East by the name of Nobody, and this man was as another Job among all the Easterners.

app.lem: Magnus namque erat iste Nemo sanctus: magnus in genere et prosapia, magnus in potencia, magnus in scientia, magnus in clemencia <et> in compassione, magnus in honore et reuerentia.
app.rdg: For that Nobody was a great saint: great in origin and lineage, great in power, great in learning, great in mercy and in compassion, great in honor and reverence.

app.lem: Hec autem omnia supra dicuntur ex sacra scriptura, cui nephas est reclamandum et contradicendum.
app.rdg: More is said of him than all others in sacred scripture, which it is a sin to protest or speak publicly against.

app.lem: Item Nemo, dico, primo fuit magnus in genere et prosapia et similis Ade, qui fuit nec creatus nec genitus sed formatus secundum prophetam dicentem: Dies formabuntur et Nemo in eis.
app.rdg:
I say first that Nobody was great in origin and lineage and was like Adam, who was not begotten or born but was formed, as the prophet says: Days will be formed and Nobody in them.
Ps. 138:16

app.lem: Fuit eciam de genere militari, unde apostolus: Nemo militans deo.
app.rdg:
Furthermore he was of a warlike origin, hence the apostle says: Nobody fighting for God.
2 Tim. 2:4

app.lem: Imo fuit nobilitate miles qui propriis et non alienis stipendiis militauit, unde illud apostoli: Nemo tenetur propriis stipendiis militare.
app.rdg:
Indeed, he was a soldier of renown, who served at his own expense and not othersâ€™, hence the following, of the apostle: Nobody serves as a soldier at his own expense.
cf. 1 Cor. 9:7

app.lem: Eciam fuit de genere non qualicumque sed regali, Ecclesiastici ii: Nemo ex regibus sumpsit exordium.
app.rdg:
Furthermore, he was not of a common but a regal origin, as in Ecclesiastes 2: Nobody began life among kings.
Wis. 7:5. Adding to the parodic effect, the in-text citation is false, and the quote has been truncated in such a way that the meaning is radically reshaped; ex regibus qualifies nemo in the original context rather than sumpsit exordium, as it does here.

app.lem: Eciam fuit de cognacione uirginis gloriose eo quod fuerit de stirpe regia et de cognacione Elizabet, Luc 1: Nemo est in cognacione tua.
app.rdg:
For he was of the relatives of a glorious virgin, who was of a regal lineage, and of the relatives of Elizabeth, as in Luke 1: Nobody is among your relatives.
Luke 1:61

app.lem: Nec fuit solum de stirpe regia sed cum ipso deo legitur semper regnaturus, Ecclesiastici xxi: 'Nemo semper regnaturus.'
app.rdg:
Nor was he only of a regal lineage, but it is said of him by God himself that he will reign forever, Ecclesiastes 21: Nobody will reign forever.
Not only is the in-text citation here false, but this is not actually a biblical quote.

app.lem: Secundo, dixi, iste Nemo magnus fuit in potencia, prius quia aperit quod deus claudit, unde illud: Deus claudit et Nemo aperit.
app.rdg:
Second, I said this Nobody was great in power, because he opens what God closes, hence the following: God closes and Nobody opens.
Rev. 3:7

app.lem: Iob 12: Si incluserit hominem, Nemo est qui aperiat.
app.rdg:
Job 12: If God imprisons a man, it is Nobody who can release him.
Job 12:14

app.lem: Item de manu dei audacter eripit, Iob 2: Cum sit Nemo qui de manu tua possit eruere.
app.rdg:
He also takes boldly from the hand of God, as in Job 2: Since it is Nobody who can pluck [me] from your hand.
Job 10:7. The truncation of the quote gives the cum clause causal force rather than the concessive of the original context.

app.lem: Item edifficat quod deus destruit, unde Iob: Si deus destruit, Nemo est qui edifficat.
app.rdg:
He also builds up what God destroys, hence Job: If God destroys it, it is Nobody who can build it up.
Job 12:14

app.lem: Item ipsum deum superat et uincitt, Ecclesiastici ii: Nemo uincit deum.
app.rdg:
He also surpasses and conquers God himself, as in Ecclesiastes 2: Nobody conquers God.
Not actually a biblical quote.

app.lem: Propterea quod deus fecit, iste Nemo illa potest facere si uoluerit, sicut dixit Nicodemus in ewangelio: Nemo potest ista signa facere que tu facis.
app.rdg:
For this reason God made it so that this Nobody could do whatever he wanted, just as Nicodemus says in the Gospel: Nobody can do the signs you do.
John 3:2

app.lem: Item gaudium ab apostolis potenter tollit, unde in ewangelio: Et gaudium tuum Nemo tollet a uobis.

rdg.note:
He also powerfully takes away joy from the apostles, hence in the Gospel: And Nobody shall take your joy away from you.
John 16:22

app.lem: Imo quod maius est, animam a Christo rapit: Animam meam Nemo tollit.
app.rdg:
Indeed, what is greater, he takes away life from Christ: Nobody takes away my life.
John 10:18

app.lem: Item duobus dominis potest seruire utiliter, quod multis uidetur inpossibile et quod est contro ewangelium, iuxta illud ut habetur in ewangelio: Nemo potest duobus dominis seruire.
app.rdg:
He can also serve two masters usefully, which seems impossible to many and is against the Gospel, just as follows, as it is had in the Gospels: Nobody can serve two masters.
Mat. 6:24
